title: Wall Street Forgot Investing Discipline in the Oil Patch
sub_head: What happened to America’s hollowed-out oil and gas industry?
body:
Paul Tice underplays the contribution of Wall Street to the new normal in oil and gas (“Why U.S. Producers Aren’t Solving the Energy Crisis,” op-ed, March 16). Yes, the feds are fickle, always have been. Same for commodity prices and the economy. The industry had managed these fluctuations by diversifying project portfolios, paying reasonable dividends and the occasional buyback to keep investors around through the price swings.
Then came unconventional shale, promising less project risk and more visibility into future production streams in return for the higher built-in cost of the technologies that facilitated the boom. Easy capital raises on the oversimplified promise of outsize returns with little risk based on new industry paradigms. Wait—are we talking tech startups?
